text.b: N T R O D U C T I O N

page.text: The Institute of Transportation Engineers (ITE) defines Traffic Calming as “the combination of
mainly physical measures that reduce the negative effects of motor vehicle use, alter driver
behavior and improve conditions for non-motorized street users.” The immediate purpose of
traffic calming is to reduce the speed and volume of traffic to acceptable levels.
The study has measured and evaluated the need for traffic calming devices within the Berkeley
Park Neighborhood located in Atlanta, GA. The City of Atlanta’s Traffic Calming Device
Implementation Guidebook, “need” is defined as the magnitude of the impact felt by the
residents of existing traffic conditions within a given neighborhood.

text.i: Figure 1 – Location Map

page.text: Using the City of Atlanta’s Traffic Calming Device Implementation Guidebook (1999) and the
ITE Traffic Calming State of the Practice (1999), this study has analyzed field data to help
provide traffic calming options for the neighborhood. This field data includes daily traffic
counts, turning movement counts, origin – destination survey, spot speed survey and accident
data evaluation. The location of the neighborhood and surrounding road network is shown in

text.b: X I S T I N G
A C I L I T I E S

page.text: Roadways classified as arterials, collectors, and above are excluded from receiving certain traffic
calming measures under Atlanta’s guidelines. Other streets may not be eligible depending on
location and individual characteristics such as designated bicycle and emergency routes. An
inventory was performed of the roads in the neighborhood. The following is a brief description
of each of these facilities. Roadway classifications were taken from the 2007 City of Atlanta

text.i: Figure 2 – City of Atlanta Functional Classification Map

text.b: B e l l e m e a d e A v e

page.text: Description / Orientation: Bellemeade Ave is an east-west, two-lane, undivided roadway
between Howell Mill Road and Northside Drive.

text.b: H o l m e s S t r e e t

page.text: Width of Roadway: ~24 feet between Howell Mill Rd and Buchanan St
~30 feet between Buchanan St and Tallulah St (including parking)
~24 feet between Tallulah St and Northside Dr
Location / Orientation: Holmes Street is an east-west, two-lane, undivided roadway
between Howell Mill Road and Northside Drive. On-street parking is striped on the north
side of the roadway between Buchanan St and Tallulah St.

text.b: V e r n e r S t r e e t

page.text: Description / Orientation: Verner Street is an east-west, two-lane, undivided residential
roadway that runs between Howell Mill Road and Buchanan Street.

text.b: A n t o n e S t r e e t

page.text: Width of Roadway: ~26 feet east of Tallulah
Description / Orientation: Antone Street is an east-west, two-lane, undivided residential
roadway between Howell Mill Road and Tallulah Drive. East of Tallulah Drive, Antone
Street is a northeast-southwest, two-lane, undivided roadway with I-1 and C-1-C zoning.

text.b: B e r k e l e y A v e

page.text: Description / Orientation: Berkeley Ave is an east-west, two-lane, undivided residential
roadway between Howell Mill Road and Forrest St. East of Forrest St, Berkeley Ave
turns north-south and dead-ends into Antone St.

text.b: F o r r e s t S t r e e t

page.text: Description / Orientation: Forrest is a two-lane, undivided roadway with various zoning
designations between Howell Mill Road and Berkeley Avenue.

text.b: B u c h a n a n S t r e e t

page.text: Description / Orientation: Buchanan Street is a north-south, two-lane, undivided
residential roadway that runs between Verner Street and Bellemeade Ave. Ninety-degree,
on-street parking is striped adjacent to The Arbors at Berkeley property on the east side
of the roadway, south of Holmes Street.

text.b: T a l l u l a h S t r e e t

page.text: Description / Orientation: Tallulah Street is a north-south, two-lane, undivided residential
roadway that runs between Antone Street and Bellemeade Ave.

text.i: Figure 3 – City of Atlanta Zoning Map

text.b: X I S T I N G
R A F F I C
A L M I N G
E V I C E S

page.text: Traffic calming has already been implemented to some degree in the neighborhood in an attempt
to limit cut-through traffic. The following is a brief description of each of the traffic calming
devices and their location. The locations of the existing traffic calming devices are also shown in

text.b: B e l l e m e a d e A v e

page.text: Bellemeade Ave has a “NO TRUCK OVER 18 TONS OR 30 FT IN LENGTH” sign located at
both the east and west ends. This restriction pertains to all semi-trucks and some single unit

text.i: Figure 4 –NO TRUCK Signs on Bellemeade Ave at Northside Dr (left) Howell Mill (right)

text.b: H o l m e s S t r e e t

page.text: Holmes Street has two speed bumps located in between Howell Mill Road and Buchanan Street.
Additionally, there is a “NO TRUCK” sign located at the east and west end of Holmes Street.
Left turns from Howell Mill Road onto Holmes Street are prohibited.

text.i: Figure 5a – NO TRUCK Signs on Holmes St at Northside Dr (left) Howell Mill (right)
Figure 5b – Southbound Howell Mill before Holmes St: NO LEFT Sign (left) THROUGH ONLY
and RIGHT ONLY (right)
Figure 5c – LEFT ONLY, NO THROUGH, and RIGHT ONLY signs on Cherokee St at Howell
Mill Road
Figure 5d – Flexible Delineators on Northside Drive at Holmes Street

page.text: The NO LEFT TURN sign on the southbound Howell Mill approach (shown in Figure 5b) is
located adjacent to the outside lane, approximately 110 feet from the center of the intersection. A
more visible location for the sign would be affixed to the mast arm. Furthermore, the flexible
delineators on Northside Drive (shown in Figure 5d) should either be repaired or replaced with

text.b: V e r n e r S t r e e t

page.text: Verner Street has two speed bumps in between Howell Mill Road and Buchanan Street.
Additionally, there is a “No Truck” sign located at the west end of Verner Street.

text.i: Figure 6 – NO TRUCK and SPEED HUMP signs on Verner St

text.b: A n t o n e S t r e e t

page.text: Antone Street has a “No Truck” and a “ROAD CLOSED TO THROUGH TRAFFIC” sign
located at the west end, at the intersection of Howell Mill Road. The “ROAD CLOSED TO
THROUGH TRAFFIC” sign is easily visible at its current location. It is recommended that the
sign be repaired and/or relocated to a more viewable location.

text.i: Figure 7 – NO TRUCK sign at Howell Mill (left) ROAD CLOSED TO THROUGH TRAFFIC at
Howell Mill (right)

text.b: B e r k e l e y A v e

page.text: Berkeley Ave has “No Truck” sign located at the intersection with Howell Mill Road. The
current placement of this sign is only visible to traffic traveling north on Howell Mill Road. It is
recommended that an additional sign be placed that will be visible to southbound vehicles, which
may be traveling from the interstate or Chattahoochee Ave.

text.i: Figure 8 – Existing Traffic Calming Measures on Berkeley Ave

text.b: O L L E C T I O N

The data collected also includes vehicle classification information.

(7:00am to 9:00am) and afternoon (4:00pm to 6:00pm) peak travel hours on Friday, April 13
This data was collected to determine the quantity of traffic cutting through the neighborhood and
on what particular residential streets. This included observers recording the inbound and
outbound activity of vehicles using the surrounding access points for the neighborhood.
Turning movement counts were collected on Friday, April 20
to determine the AM and PM
peak hours and volumes at key intersections. These counts were collected at the following

neighborhood to determine the severity of speeding within Berkeley Park.

The location of the various aforementioned neighborhood counts is shown in Figure 10.

text.b: R A F F I C
N A L Y S I S

page.text: The purpose of a traffic volume analysis in relation to traffic calming studies is to determine
whether the amount of traffic on a residential road is at tolerable levels. Many times it is difficult
to develop a consensus on what is considered as tolerable. In order to quantify the levels of
traffic in the Berkeley Park neighborhood, several types of data were collected. Bi-directional
tube counts were collected at 15 locations throughout the Berkeley Park Neighborhood on
. Additionally, origin-destination information was collected through license

text.b: D a i l y V o l u m e C o u n t s

page.text: As expected, of the roadway segments studied, the highest volumes were observed on
Bellemeade Avenue. Because of its proximity to commercial land uses, signalized access points
at both ends, and lack of alternative routes nearby, Bellemeade Avenue is considered (by the
motoring public in the area) to be the preferred route traveling between Howell Mill Road and
Northside Drive. Among the date collected along Bellemeade Ave, the daily traffic volumes
ranged from 7,380 vehicles/day to 9,322 vehicles/day. The daily traffic volumes for the other
Traffic volumes are not the single criterion for evaluating neighborhood traffic problems. There
are two different types of motorists who travel on residential streets. The typical majority are
local residential motorists, who live in the area and travel on a particular residential street to get
to or from their home. Traveling on these residential streets is a necessity for these motorists.
Traffic calming measures will not affect the amount of locally bound traffic unless they are so
severe or restrictive as to “degenerate” motor vehicle trips. The other type of motorists traveling
on residential streets is sometimes referred to as “cut-through” motorists. These motorists are
using the residential streets as a short-cut to by-pass nearby collector or arterial streets which
may be congested or out-of-direction to their destination.

text.b: B e l l e m e a d e A v e n u e

page.text: Bellemeade Avenue is the highest volume roadway on which counts were collected. It is
classified by the City of Atlanta as a local roadway; however, at over 9,000 vehicles per day it is
functionally more like a collector and is used by the local motorists as the preferred route
between Howell Mill Road and Northside Drive in the area. A majority of traffic on this road is
anticipated to be unrelated to the Berkeley Park residential area.
There are several reasons as to why Bellemeade Avenue is the most utilized route in this area. In
comparison to other neighborhood roads, Bellemeade is the most equipped to handle the Howell-
Northside traffic as it is the only route to have signals at either end. Furthermore, apart from the
residential Berkeley Park traffic, this route serves adjacent commercial zoned properties which
have property frontage on Bellemeade Avenue. Alternate east-west collectors include Collier
Street (0.62 miles south). It is believed that if traffic were to be
diverted from Bellemeade Ave, the next most likely place for vehicles to go would be less
desirable routes like Verner St, Holmes St, and Antone St. Therefore, traffic calming measures
have not been recommended for this route. Once closer alternate east-west routes are established
(such as the extension of Trabert Ave), it is more feasible that traffic could be diverted away
from Bellemeade Avenue without spilling into the other neighborhood streets.
It is important to consider traffic diversion in the overall design. If traffic calming measures are
installed on only one route, a negative consequence could include shifting the problems to other
undesired locations. A positive result involves diversion of traffic to higher order roads that are
better able to handle it. The City of Atlanta guidelines state that increases of traffic on adjacent
local streets are acceptable based on a curve ranging from a maximum 150 veh/day – 400
veh/day (depending on current traffic volumes). No increases are allowed on local streets
exceeding 3,000 vehicles per day. In this case, implementation of traffic calming in Berkeley
Park will shift traffic to Bellemeade Avenue, which currently has daily volumes of greater than
9,000 vehicles. The Atlanta guidelines also state that “an increase in traffic volumes that exceeds
the Impact Threshold Curve does not constitute a fatal flaw to the project unless Traffic and
Transportation makes that determination prior to project implementation.” It should be noted that
the increases in through traffic on Bellemeade Avenue would be small in relation to the amounts
already present and limited based on current volumes within the Berkeley Park study area.

text.b: T r u c k P e r c e n t a g e s

page.text: As part of this analysis, the percent of heavy trucks was also determined from the count data. For
the purposes of this study, trucks are considered as vehicles that are FHWA Vehicle
Classification 5 and higher. The range of percent of heavy trucks that were present at each tube
count location, on average, ranged from 3% to 7%. One tube count on Verner Street was found
to have a much higher truck percent, with a considerable makeup of 23.65% of heavy trucks
traveling in the eastbound direction. The heavy truck percent of the total average daily traffic

text.b: O r i g i n - D e s t i n a t i o n C o u n t s

page.text: An origin – destination study was completed to determine the extent of cut-through traffic
through the Berkeley Park Neighborhood study area during the AM and PM peak hours. Cut-
through motorists do not have a trip end in the vicinity of the residential street in which they are
traveling. This data was determined from a license plate survey that was completed on Friday,
April 20th from 7:00am – 9:00am and 4:00pm – 6:00pm. From the four hours of data, an AM
and PM peak hour was chosen. It was found that the AM peak hour is from 8:00am – 9:00am
and the PM peak hour is from 5:00pm – 6:00pm.
The results of the analysis indicate that the highest volume of entering cut-through traffic (in the
AM or PM peak hour) occurs at Verner Street / Howell Mill Road. The majority of the motorists
using this intersection are turning left from Howell Mill Road onto Verner Street. The highest
amount of exiting cut-through traffic was found to be at Holmes Street / Northside Dr. All of the
motorists using this intersection are exiting the neighborhood to turn right, onto Northside Drive.
In the PM peak hour, equally high exiting cut-through volumes were seen at Buchanan Street /
Bellemeade Ave. Cut-through motorists that are exiting onto Bellemeade Ave are exiting right
and left with the majority making a right onto Bellemeade Ave.
The most used cut-through paths were determined using the direction of travel information
collected with the license plate survey data. Using this data, a record was kept of the entering
and exiting locations and the time spent within the neighborhood. Travel patterns for cut-through
vehicles were determined using this information in combination with the layout of the
neighborhood routes. After all cut-through traffic was identified, the most utilized paths of the
cut-through traffic were then determined. Cut-through volumes for both the AM and PM peak
hours along the heaviest routes are shown in Table 4 and Table 5, respectively.
This data indicates that most cut-through traffic is bypassing Bellemeade Ave by traveling south
on Howell Mill Road (likely after turning from Chattahoochee Ave) and turning left onto either
Antone Street or Verner Street then exiting towards right onto Northside Dr. Another pattern that
emerged was that vehicles were using Berkeley Park as a turn-around to avoid the left turn lane

text.i: Figure 11 – Backups in Left turn lane on Chattahoochee Ave at Howell Mill Road

page.text: As shown in Figure 11, the queues on Chattahoochee Avenue are worse for the left turn lane
than the queues for the right turn lane. It is conceived that many vehicles are using the right turn
lane in combination with the neighborhood streets to travel either north on Howell Mill or
towards Northside Drive to avoid these queues.

text.b: V o l u m e s A n a l y s i s C o n c l u s i o n s

page.text: The City of Atlanta’s Traffic Calming Device Implementation Guidebook states that tolerable
limits for traffic volumes / cut-through traffic components are not easily defined, nor is there a
easily reached consensus as to what constitutes “too much” traffic. Therefore, the reference
suggests that volumes of through-traffic of fewer than 2.0 vehicles per minute are deemed as
“tolerable”. Through traffic volumes between 2.0 – 2.5 vehicles are deemed as a “moderate
problem”, and through traffic volumes greater than 2.5 vehicles per minute are considered a
Traffic managers in several communities have need to strike a balance between an approach that
relies on fixed thresholds (or warrants as used for traffic signals in MUTCD) and “best technical
judgment.” The strongest argument for these thresholds is standardization, while the counter-
argument is that every traffic calming application is unique. According to the ITE Traffic
Calming State of the Practice, “Volume impacts are much more complex and case-specific than
are speed impacts. They depend on the entire network of which a street is a part, not just on the
characteristics of the street itself. In particular, volume impacts depend fundamentally on the
split between local and through traffic.” In this area, the highest through volumes for one road
reaches 45-53% of the traffic, and many residents in the Berkeley Park area consider these levels
of cut-through traffic to be unsafe for their neighborhood.
Volume control measures fall into three classes: those that preclude through traffic; those that
discourage but still allow through traffic; and those that are neutral with respect to through traffic
other than to slow it down. For example, street closures and/or restricting certain movements
would preclude through traffic, adding speed bumps would discourage through traffic, and a
traffic circle would cause minimal diversion. The effect of speed control measures on traffic
volumes vary with the degree of speed reduction. Route choice depends on travel times, and a
route that is traffic calmed becomes less attractive relative to alternate routes. Impacts are also
dependent on the availability and quality of alternative routes.
Specific recommendations for improvements that will reduce traffic volumes are presented in the
Recommendations section of this report. The average daily traffic volumes are shown in Figure
13. The percentage of heavy trucks at various locations is shown in Figure 14. Peak hour
volumes are shown in Figure 15. The percentages of cut through volumes at various locations are
shown in Figure 16, and total peak hour cut-through volumes are shown in Figure 17.

text.b: P E E D I N G
N A L Y S I S

page.text: In traffic engineering, speed distributions are typically represented by 85th percentile speeds. It
is not the highest speed any motorist travels, but is high enough to represent the probable safe
end of the speed distribution. The posted speed limit throughout the neighborhood is 25 mph,
except for the 30 mph speed limit on Howell Mill Road.
The City of Atlanta’s Traffic Calming Device Implementation Guidebook has determined that a
percentile speed exceeds the posted speed limit. The
problem is classified as moderate or serious depending on where the problem falls in between
two threshold lines. A moderate condition for a 25 mph roadway is identified as an 85
percentile speed that is above 25 mph but below 35 mph. A serious problem for a 25 mph
percentile speed that is greater than 35 mph.
A spot speed survey was completed to determine the percentage of total motorists who exceed
the speed limit. This data was collected from tube counts on Friday, April 13
percentile speed is the speed at which 85% of the observed vehicles are traveling at or below.
This speed was determined at each tube count location. The result of the analysis is shown in

text.i: Figure 17A – 85th Percentile Speeds

page.text: The analysis indicates that few road segments were found to have the 85
traveling at or below the posted speed limit of 25 mph. The majority of streets were shown to
have some degree of speeding. When comparing the 85
percentile speeds to the City of Atlanta
thresholds, the results indicate that most road segments are classified as having “moderate”
speeding problem. Holmes Street west of Tallulah St has a “serious” speeding problem.
Speed control measures are of three types: vertical measures, horizontal measures, and
narrowings. A vertical measure would include speed humps while horizontal measures include
traffic circles and lateral shifts. Narrowings include measures such as neckdowns, which use
curb extensions or center islands. Vertical and horizontal devices tend to be more effective in
reducing speeds because a physical impediment is in place. Narrowings can help to improve
pedestrian safety, but are not as effective in reducing speeds. Another approach sometimes used
for speed reduction includes psycho-perceptive controls like centerline and edge line striping,
unique message signs, transverse markings, and small setbacks. These alternative approaches
have not been reported to have success in local street applications.
Speed impacts of traffic calming measures depend primarily on geometrics and spacing.
Geometrics determine the speeds at which motorists travel through slow points. Spacing
determines the extent to which motorists speed up between slow points. In regards to speed
humps/tables, the traffic speed is usually lowered to one third of the original speed at the point of
installation (location of speed hump) and 3-6 mph higher than one third of the original speed
Specific recommendations for improvements that will reduce vehicular speeds are presented in
the Recommendations section of this report. The 85
neighborhood are shown in Figure 18. For comparison, the 95

text.i: Figure 17B – 95th Percentile Speeds

text.b: C C I D E N T
N V E S T I G A T I O N

page.text: “Perhaps the most compelling effect of traffic calming is in the area of safety. By slowing traffic,
eliminating conflicting movements, and sharpening drivers’ attention, traffic calming may result
in fewer collisions. And, because of lower speeds, when collisions do occur, they may be less
serious.” ITE - Traffic Calming State of the Practice (1999)
Accident data was obtained for internal intersections as well as intersections on the fringe of the
neighborhood. These accidents have occurred within the last 24 months. The intersections that
experienced accidents are show below in Table 6.
The intersection which has the highest accident volume and serves as an entry/exit point to the
neighborhood is Howell Mill Road / Verner Street. This intersection experiences a high volume
of cut-through traffic as discussed later in the report. Accident volumes for intersections in the
study area can be seen in Figure 19.

text.b: O N C L U S I O N S
E C O M M E N D A T I O N S
S u m m a r y o f F i n d i n g s

page.text: The two main traffic issues that are present in the neighborhood include a “moderate” to
“serious” speeding problem as well as targeted routes with a large percentage of cut-through
and/or truck traffic. Most cut-through traffic in the neighborhood is originating from the
southbound movement on Howell Mill Road (as an alternate to Bellemeade Avenue) and the
eastbound movement from Chattahoochee Avenue (to avoid queues in the left turn lane).
Speeding is most prevalent on wide-lane, straight, and/or downhill segments within the
neighborhood. Traffic calming devices have been recommended where appropriate to reduce
speed through the neighborhood and reduce and/or eliminate cut-through volumes.

text.b: T r a f f i c D i v e r s i o n a s a n A r e a W i d e A p p r o a c h

page.text: The routes closer to Bellemeade Avenue and Chattahoochee Avenue (mainly Holmes Street and
Verner St near Howell Mill Road) have been shown to be the most convenient segments for cut-
through traffic; therefore, these routes have been given harsher volume reduction measures than
areas in which speeding is the major concern. By installing traffic calming measures that prohibit
(rather than merely discourage) cut-through traffic on Holmes St and Verner St, these trips will
be forced to use alternate routes.
It is important to consider traffic diversion in the overall design. If traffic calming measures are
installed on only one route, a negative consequence could include shifting the problems to other
undesired locations. A positive result involves diversion of traffic to higher order roads that are
better able to handle it. As discussed earlier in this report, Bellemeade Avenue is the more
appropriate route for this traffic, rather than the southern portion of the Berkeley Park
neighborhood. As Antone St also has a cut-through problem, and the segment is relatively close
to the prohibited routes, an additional restrictive measure has been recommended there to
prevent cut-through traffic from taking advantage of Antone Street’s straight, downhill nature
and few stops. There are very few cut-through routes originating at Berkeley Avenue and Forrest
Street from Howell Mill Road. The distance of Berkeley Avenue and Forrest Street from the
alternate Bellemeade Avenue route, the larger amount of stop controlled intersections, and the
amount of turns required for through traffic are likely to discourage traffic from using these
streets as an alternate to Bellemeade Avenue. As an additional precautionary measure, and to
help abate speeding, some milder calming measures have been recommended for these areas.
As an overall neighborhood recommendation, the installation of “No Thru Traffic” signs at each
entrance along Howell Mill Road and Northside Drive is recommended. This traffic calming
device could be implemented quickly and is relatively less expensive than other traffic calming
devices. Recommended signage and location is shown in Figure 20.

text.b: H o w e l l M i l l R d / C h a t t a h o o c h e e A v e / H o l m e s S t I n t e r s e c t i o n

page.text: The intersection of Holmes St / Howell Mill Rd / Chattahoochee Ave has signs restricting
movements that would prohibit eastbound traffic from Chattahoochee Avenue and southbound
traffic from Howell Mill Road; however, these trips are still occurring. The NO LEFT TURN
sign on the southbound Howell Mill approach is located adjacent to the outside lane,
approximately 110 feet from the center of the intersection. A more visible location for the sign
would be affixed to the mast arm, as shown below. An additional improvement would be to
install a concrete island in the hatched area of the eastbound right turn lane to prevent vehicles
from making the prohibited through movement from Chattahoochee Ave onto Holmes St using
A recommendation to further prohibit these turning movements, and consequently all eastbound
traffic, would be to construct a half closure on the southern site of Holmes Street, just west of the
first residential driveway. This placement would act to create a barrier between the commercial
and residential areas of Berkeley Park.
Half closures are used to help eliminate cut-through traffic by only allowing a one-way
(westbound in this case) travel movement. The recommendation for this improvement includes
temporary use of flexible delineators and striping to only allow westbound traffic to exit Holmes
Street to allow neighbors to experience impacts prior to construction. This temporary traffic
calming device can then be analyzed to determine if desirable for the residents. A more
permanent obstruction can be installed consisting of landscaping, parking bays or other physical

text.b: H o l m e s S t r e e t

page.text: Holmes Street experiences a large portion of the neighborhood cut-through traffic. Cut-through
motorists are using Holmes Street as an east-west route from Howell Mill Road to Northside
Drive. Additionally, cut-through motorist are crossing Holmes Street at Buchanan Street and
Tallulah Street. Some of the cut-through traffic is choosing to not travel on Bellemeade Ave to
Northside Drive, but rather through the neighborhood. Holmes Street was also seen to have the
largest speeding problem measured in the Berkeley Park neighborhood. 85
Holmes Street indicates a moderate to serious speeding problem between Buchannan Street and
Tallulah Street, with speeds averaging around 35 mph.
Speeds can be decreased by converting extra lane width to install parallel parking spaces at
strategic sections on the roadway to slow vehicular traffic through lateral displacement in the
direction of travel. This “chicane” type of horizontal curvature will require drivers to slow down
in order to navigate the curve safely. A level one recommendation includes using flexible
delineators to create the desired parallel parking space boundary and horizontal curvature along
the roadway. These measures should offer reductions in speed and some abatement in cut-
through and truck volumes. A concept design for Holmes Street is shown below. A larger design

text.i: Top: Conceptual layout for Holmes St; Left: Serpentine Treatment; Right: Striping & Flexible
Delineators used as Temporary Measure

text.b: V e r n e r S t r e e t

page.text: Verner Street has the highest amount of entering cut-through traffic in both the AM and PM peak
hours. Most cut-through traffic is observed making a southbound left turn from Howell Mill
Road onto Verner Street, then turning left or right onto Bellemeade Ave. This cut-through
movement is motivated by two possible scenarios. The intersection of Howell Mill Road /
Bellemeade Avenue is a signalized intersection with only a 100’ dedicated southbound left turn
lane and no protected left turn phase. Southbound vehicles may choose not to turn left onto
Bellemeade either due to limited gaps in northbound traffic or long queues within or past the left
turn lane. The other possible scenario involves vehicles traveling east on Chattahoochee Avenue
turning right onto Howell Mill Road rather than waiting in the long queues for the left turn lane.
In order to limit cut-through traffic from entering Berkeley Park on Verner Street, it is
recommended that a half closure be constructed east of the Flip Burger driveway as shown in the
following images. Half closures are used to help eliminate cut-through traffic by only allowing a
one-way (westbound in this case) travel movement. The recommendation for this improvement
includes a permanent obstruction consisting of landscaping and/or concrete along the road. A
concept design is shown below. A larger design is available in the Appendix.

text.i: Conceptual layout for Holmes St

text.b: A n t o n e S t r e e t & B e r k e l e y A v e n u e

page.text: Antone Street is the second highest entrance point for cut-through traffic in the AM peak hour.
Cut-through traffic is making a southbound left turn from Howell Mill Road onto Antone Street
rather than utilizing Bellemeade Avenue. This movement is motivated by two possible scenarios.
The intersection of Howell Mill Road / Bellemeade Avenue is a signalized intersection with a
100’ dedicated left turn lane and no protected left turn phase. Southbound vehicles may choose
not to turn left onto Bellemeade either due to limited gaps in northbound traffic or long queues
within or past the left turn lane. The other possible scenario involves vehicles traveling east on
Chattahoochee Avenue turning right onto Howell Mill Road rather than waiting in the long
queues for the left turn lane.
Berkeley Avenue does not currently have a significant amount of cut-through traffic when
compared to other routes within the Berkeley Park Neighborhood; however, the construction and
reinforcement of traffic calming on Holmes St, Verner St, and Antone St could cause a shift of
cut-through trips further south to Berkeley Ave. Furthermore, straight road segments along with
an increase in cut-through traffic on Berkeley Ave could compound the speeding related issues
that are currently present on more utilized routes today.
percentile speeds on Antone Street indicate a moderate speeding problem, with speeds
averaging around 30 mph. Both the wide lanes and straight downhill slopes (eastbound) on
Antone Street may contribute to increased vehicular speeds. Even though heavy vehicles are
prohibited, truck traffic was counted as many as 52 daily trips on Antone Street (east of
Based on input from neighbors, a narrowing of Antone Street and Berkeley Street to 8’-9’ lanes
east of Howell Mill Road was considered to be acceptable using a combination of striping and
curb extensions on alternating sides of the roadway. This design would include a combination of
chokers that will reduce the width of the lanes and speed humps to slow and discourage traffic
even further. These measures are predominately aimed at speeding issues but also have been
shown to have an impact on cut-through traffic by increasing travel times on the route to which

text.i: Top: Conceptual layout for Antone Street and Berkeley Ave; Bottom: Close-up of speed hump
and narrowing

text.b: T a l l u l a h
S t r e e t
F o r r e s t
S t r e e t

page.text: The residents have requested that speed humps be considered for Tallulah Street and Forrest
Street as part of an overall traffic plan for the neighborhood. When determining the ideal spacing
of speed humps, the deciding factor becomes the desired 85
shown that on a flat road, 260 to 500 foot intervals are ideal in maintaining a speed of 25-30
mph. This spacing varies from one road to another, and should be determined on specific road
characteristics such as grade, length of road, number of intersections and noise. Approximate
speed hump locations, for the roads listed above, are shown in the Appendix.

text.b: A d d i t i o n a l
I m p r o v e m e n t s

page.text: The residents have requested that further improvements be implemented to increase safety and
Addition of NO PARKING designation on Antone Street within the functional area of its
intersection with Howell Mill Road. The concern is for conflicts between two-way traffic
entering and exiting Berkeley Park at this location.
Additional signage adjacent to the Berkeley Park neighborhood indicating the 35 MPH
speed limit on Howell Mill Road, particularly for southbound traffic traveling from the I-
Repairs / maintenance at missing sections of curb along Bellemeade Avenue.

text.i: Locations of textured crosswalks at all-way stop locations

text.b: S u m m a r y o f R e c o m m e n d a t i o n s

page.text: The general theme of the recommendations for cut-through traffic involve utilizing Bellemeade
Avenue for non-residential trips and prohibiting the use of other east-west routes to cut-through
traffic. The east-west routes that are closest to Bellemeade Avenue (Holmes St and Verner St)
are treated with half-closures. Routes that were further south (Antone St, Berkeley Avenue, and
Forrest St) with fewer seen cut-through trips were treated with speed calming measures that
would also to have an impact on cut-through traffic by increasing travel times on the routes to
which they are added. The traffic calming measures designed to explicitly prohibit traffic are
Holmes Street: Relocate the NO LEFT TURN sign from Howell Mill Road onto the mast
arm for the approach; Construct a raised island in the eastbound right turn lane from
Chattahoochee Ave; Install a half closure on the southern side of Holmes Street (just west
Verner Street: Install an half closure for approximately 50’ on the southern side of
Holmes Street (just east of the Flip Burger driveway)
Traffic calming recommendations aimed at speeding use either vertical deflection (humps),
horizontal deflection (chicanes or chokers), or both to provide physical impediments that would
cause drivers to slow in order to drive over or steer around them. These measures have been
recommended on segments that exhibited classic markers for speeding problems, such as straight
and/or downhill segments with areas to build up speed before being forced to stop. Specifically
Chicanes to horizontally deflect traffic with protected parking bays striped from
Narrowing of the road to 8’-9’ lanes using chokers using a combination of
striping and curb extensions on alternating sides of the roadway
Speed humps at the curb extension to increase their effectiveness and to slow and
Narrowing of the road to 8’-9’ lanes using chokers using a combination of
striping and curb extensions on alternating sides of the roadway
Speed humps at the curb extension to increase their effectiveness and to slow and
Forrest St: Installation of speed humps per city of Atlanta standards
Tallulah Street: Installation of speed humps per city of Atlanta
Detailed recommendations for each of the streets listed above are included in the previous
section of this report. Concept designs and preliminary cost estimates are provided in the
